Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Global Test for Non-linear Responses of Grassland Diversity to Nitrogen Deposition
Award.AbstractNarration:
It has received less attention than climate change, but nitrogen deposition from air pollution could also have major ecological effects. One well-documented effect of adding nitrogenous fertilizers to grasslands is loss of species due to heightened competition. Although deposition from the air is so far mostly adding smaller amounts of nitrogen, accumulated effects could cause similar losses. This project will advance our understanding of how nitrogen deposition is likely to affect biodiversity in grasslands worldwide in the future. In partnership with an international network of research sites, researchers will measure incoming nitrogen, accumulation of nitrogen in the soil, and abundances of plant species over three years to discover which levels of nitrogen deposition are likely to trigger species loss. Because reducing nitrogen pollution can be economically costly, it is important to be able to weigh these costs against benefits to conservation of diversity and other resources such as grazing lands. Research results will thus be disseminated to managers in the U.S. to help inform policy with science. The project will also train technicians and undergraduate students and provide research experiences for two high school teachers who will pass on their knowledge to classes.

The project will test the hypothesis that the relationship between nitrogen deposition and species loss is determined by previous nitrogen availability, co-limitation of plant growth by other nutrients, climate, and species traits. At about 30 of the 75 sites in the international Nutrient Network, researchers and collaborators will install nitrogen addition treatments designed to mimic accelerated deposition and deploy ion-exchange resin collectors to measure nitrogen availability to plants. These treatments and measurements will be combined with existing nutrient treatments and measurements of nitrogen input, climate, and plant species composition to provide a large data set for Bayesian analyses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nutrients, particularly nitrogen, are critical inputs for agricultural production. Through this input humans have improved food production, but natural processes, such as run-off, evaporation, and precipitation, move nutrients regionally and globally. This has increased the bioavailability of these nutrients in non-agricultural areas.  The consequences of this increase include higher productivity and changes in plant dominance and biodiversity.  However, the mechanisms and generality of these changes are unknown. Ecologists are using globally distributed experiments, such as the Nutrient Network, to determine the universal response of organisms to this additional nutrient input. 

 

This study tests if simple, inexpensive collectors can be used to directly and accurately measure wet nutrient deposition around the globe.  Although actual nutrient deposition rates are measured, the sensors are expensive and widely dispersed. Therefore, point-specific nutrient deposition rates are only estimated from models. This study used the infrastructure and data of Nutrient Network to both distribute the wet nutrient deposition collectors and test the effects of site-specific nutrient deposition rates on biodiversity and ecological processes.

 

The results of this study will improve our understanding of regional and global nutrient deposition.  Agriculture will benefit economically because if ambient levels are known, nutrient application efficiency can improve. Ecological science will benefit from a better understanding of nutrient effects on biodiversity and production.  By implementing this project through a research network we have fostered collaborative ethic among our peers. Finally, this study has influenced future scientists, by training numerous undergraduate students in research protocols and best practices. We have also engaged science teachers through the Research Experience for Teacher’s (RET) program, which will transfer knowledge of ecological principles and study design to high school students.
